name: Wound Infection, Post-trauma
clinical_setting:
Uncomplicated, mild or moderate wound infection (usually outpatient management in afebrile patient).
Debridement of wound may be indicated: Obtain culture and sensitivity, check Gram stain.
Give tetanus prophylaxis and vaccine if indicated.
See also, Wounds, Bites and Burns: Overview.
Complicated, severe (usually hospitalized patient who is often febrile):
Debridement as needed
Collect specimen for culture and sensitivity
Tetanus toxoid if indicated
etiologies: Polymicrobic (Microbial flora dependent on nature of the trauma):
Acinetobacter species; esp. problem in soldiers infected in Afghanistan, Iraq

primary_regimens.notes: If Gram-negative bacilli are suspected: add Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875/125 mg po bid or a fluoroquinolone).

primary_regimens.drug: Piperacillin-tazobactam or Imipenem-cilastatin or Meropenem or Ertapenem) + Vancomycin
primary_regimens.dosage: 15-20 mg/kg IV q8-12h to achieve preferred target AUC24 400-600 µg/mL x hr (see vancomycin AUC dosing calculator); alternative target is trough of 15-20 µg/mL

alternative_regimens.dosage:
200 mg IV (over 60 min) loading dose and then 100 mg (over 30 min) q24 h
100 mg IV over 30 min bid on day one and then 100 mg iv over 30 min q24h
450 mg po q24h on days 1 and 2 and then 300 mg po q24h
alternative_regimens.notes: Do not use an older tetracycline for reason of resistance and/or clinical failures.

alternative_regimens.drug: (Vancomycin (as above) or Daptomycin 6 mg/kg IV q 24h or Linezolid 600 mg IV/po q12h or Telavancin 10 mg/kg IV q24h) + either Ciprofloxacin or Levofloxacin IV

antimicrobial_stewardship: In randomized trial TMP-SMX and Clindamycin both regimens efficacious, but fewer recurrences with Clindamycin: Clin Infect Dis 62:1505, 2016
If S. aureus are Erythromycin-resistant in vitro, may have inducible resistance to Clindamycin; make sure lab checks if using the latter.
comments: Acinetobacter sp. infection seen in traumatic wounds in soldiers (Iraq, Afghanistan, elsewhere in Middle East): Clin Infect Dis 47:444, 2008.
